text: A group of 11 YEAR-OLD GIRLS stand in three rows on a hom made wooden stage. A banner reads, "The Secondary Fourth School for Girls-Riyadh East." A TEACHER eyes them skeptically.
Again, from the beginning. She pushes "play" on a small tape recorder on the floor.

It's time for Jihad; it's the only choice. The war is boiling, calling. The front row has four girls, one of whom is WAJDA, (11), cute face with big, smart eyes. They all sing in tune except for her. She's looking away singing absentmindedly, missing most of the words. Wajda watches two older girls, FATIN and FATIMA, pass by. Wajda waves to them as she sings. She looks at the teacher, now scowling at her, tucks her hands in her pocket and tries to follow the other girls. all look similar except for Wajda. The SONG halts abruptly as the teacher hits "Stop" on the tape recorder. The girls' voices trail off.

Wajda! Step to the front, please. Wajda makes her way out of the rows of girls. NOURA, (11) sweet and perfect type, bumps into her, smiles and fills place in the front line. Wajda stands in front of the lin girls alone.
Why don’t you show us all how well you sing? Start with the first verse. Wajda becomes very nervous. Her face reddens and she star hard at the floor, she tries to sing, but her mouth clamp tight.

Well? If you don’t want to share that “beautiful” voice of yours with us... The teacher gestures towards the tape recorder. Wajda stares at the floor as she sits down next to the ta recorder, scowling. The line is much more unified now. The Teacher smiles wit satisfaction then glares at her.
Well?! Like a professional DJ, Wajda's hand rewinds the tape, st it and hits "Play" all in one motion.

It's time for Jihad; it's the only choice. The war is boiling, calling. The horses are prepared; the battle will start. War heals wounds way better than suppressing anger. If our religion is humiliated, heaven calls and our fate is written. Where are the proud men to answer the calls? Allhu Akbar is our song; It is our light and the fire we fight with!

head_text.subj: THE CHORUS CONTINUES THROUGH THE TITLES
STATIC BLENDS OVER THE SONG LIKE A RADIO TUNING TO ANOTHE

text: CHANNEL and then...

In her small, sparsely decorated room between a single be and a window covered completely with wallpaper, Wajda hit "record" on her tape recorder as the ROCK SONG continues. Dancing and moving to the beat, she insures that a cord f the window is properly connected to the radio antennae. She writes down the song on a track list labeled "Wajda's Awesome Mix Tape, Vol. 7." Next, she counts out homemade bracelets and puts them in small plastic bags. Finally, s puts on her black converse high-tops with colored laces. As she waits for the ROCK SONG to end, she looks through half open door to her MOTHER, busy drying her hair.

WAJDA'S MOTHER (33), struggles with a broken hair-dryer a she straightens her beautiful long hair. She is petite, w a definite sparkle in her eye, but right now she’s frustrated. The brush becomes too hot and she quickly dri the rest of her hair without it.
Wajda takes some money from a drawer and puts it in her pocket. She hits "Stop" on the tape recorder and runs out

Wajda's Mother twists her hair and adds colored clips. Sh moves to the kitchen and adds cups of cardamom and coffee boiling water in an old pot. Outside a car HONKS its horn In rapid motions, her Mother takes the over-boiling coffe puts it in a thermos and grabs her notebooks. Wajda enters, drops her backpack and hurries behind, carr the rest of her Mother's supplies. The Mother grabs keys from a hook by the entrance. A stri of blue prayer beads fall to the floor. She puts them bac the hook, pulls her veil over her face and turns to Wajda
Don't forget your key, and don't lock the upper lock. Your Father may be coming later after his night shift.
A Pakistani Driver, IQBAL, (late 20's), squats in front o old van, sticking the broken headlights on with tape. He turns as Wajda and her Mother emerge.
(In broken Arabic, bossy) It very long way, Madame! Other teachers we are taking, very long way. You late every day! No taking you late.
She's not late! You just came! I saw you - five minutes not even!

I no talk to you little girl, I talk to your Mother, she is late! Iqbal enters the car and slams the door. A picture of a c smiling child wearing traditional Indian dress with flowe in her hair, falls to the car’s floor. Iqbal picks up the picture and cleans it carefully then puts it back on the car’s counter.

Don't worry about him. Okay, yalla bye! (to Iqbal) ) No problem, Iqbal. You take lots of money; let's have some quiet for the long drive. She takes her things from Wajda and quickly enters the va The bus jolts away. Wajda is about to walk back into the house when the minivan swerves to avoid an oncoming car, almost crashing into it. She watches until it disappears, worried for her Mother.
Wajda grabs her backpack, stopping by the mirror. She loo at herself and touches her hair, then puts on her abbayah

Concrete houses line the street. All the windows are cove in aluminum. A typical middle class neighborhood in Riyad Saudi Arabia. Groups of girls walk to school, completely covered in abbayahs and veils, distinguishable only by their differe backpacks. Taxis and minivans pass by full of covered wom in black. Wajda exits her gate and walks towards school. Suddenly a rock flies by her feet and knocks a soda can from its pla She looks up to see her FATHER (35), smiling and tossing another rock up in the air, playfully. Dark and handsome with short soft black hair and a well groomed mustache, he wears a worn-out blue oil-man’s unif
Watch this! He flings the rock towards another can just past her on t wall. She ducks but looks over to see the can fly from it place. Wajda searches and picks up another rock.
Oh yeah, check this out! Full of bravado, she flings the rock at a milk carton nea his feet but it falls short and BOUNCES off target.
Ha! Keep practicing. You're getting there!
Look who's back! Where have you been? She smiles, runs and gives him a big hug.
Oof. Look at this. He pulls out a shiny black rock from his pocket.
It's volcanic, from the Empty Quarter. It has a great velocity. It'll help your aim. Now get going. She takes it, beaming. He taps her on her head and she ru off to school.
We left the door unlocked. Mom's been waiting for you all week! The father’s eyes flicker at the mention of the mother. H passes his hand over his untidy black hair feeling uneasy

ABDULLAH, (11), a skinny, bright-eyed boy, stands near th entryway, setting up a billboard. He peeks inside at Wajd she enters and heads for the candy bars, picking out chocolate. She sees him and smiles. Abdullah immediately looks away. He busies himself with the billboard, attaching a large election poster of an overweight, mustached man on a chai that looks like a throne. The poster reads: "Vote for me Municipal Council. Your glorious representation." Abdullah's bicycle stands next to the board with his book clamped onto a rack on the back. Out of the corner of his eye he watches Wajda approach, munching on a breakfast sandwich. He quickly brushes his into place and acts busy and important.
(laughing) Huh, what is this, an advertisement for mustache products?! Abdullah smiles, composes himself and faces her with an annoyed look.
Smart-ass, it's a mustache so strong a falcon could stand on it!
A falcon? An airplane could land on that thing! Abdullah smiles but then sees a group of boys approaching quickly snatches the sandwich out of her hands and runs o
Thanks for buying me breakfast!

Hey! If it's a race you're after don't blame it on the sandwich!  10 She breaks into a run after him. They race through the streets, away from the boys, switching positions in the r She overtakes him, snatches the sandwich and looks back, pumping her arms in the air, relishing the victory. Away from the other boys, Abdullah now smiles at her. He runs back to the billboard.

Wajda walks on to school eating her sandwich happily. She continues the target practice with her beloved new rock, aiming at several objects as she goes. Suddenly out of nowhere, Abdullah snatches her veil as he zips past her on his bicycle. Wajda falls hard to the gro her sandwich now covered in dirt. Her hair is exposed. It covered in curls and colored hair clips like her Mother's but sloppier. Abdullah points.
(laughing) What is all this? She puts her hands over her head, embarrassed.

(indignantly) It's so in fashion now. Abdullah continues laughing. She runs furiously after him dangles the veil mockingly behind him as he rides ahead. Pitying her, Abdullah finally slows down. Wajda reaches o and rips the veil from his hands but falls hard to the ground, into a puddle of mud. Abdullah stops. Wajda angrily gets up and screams at him.
Stupid! How can I go to school like this? He’s about to get off his bicycle and help her when sever boys come out of a nearby store. Abdullah thinly disguise his guilty look with a mocking smile.
Did you really think you could catch me?  11
(confused) I did catch you! You and your stupid bicycle.

Yeah right. Now you’re late and covered in mud. If you had a “stupid” bicycle you could go home and change. But you don’t, so you can’t. Wajda, hurt, looks up as he slowly pedals away with the o boys, all on bikes as well, talking and laughing. They ri in circles, challenging each other and showing off. Wajda clutches her soaking veil, watching them all ride a together, happy and free.
(to herself) I’1ll get one and show you. As she smooths out her veil, now too dirty to put back on she doesn’t see Abdullah glancing back with a pained, sor look.

location: INSIDE THE FRONT GATE OF THE SCHOOL

text: Wajda tries to blend in with the other girls and sneak in MS. HUSSA, (35), the pretty but stoic principal, stands inside the wall that protects the privacy of the school entrance. A loud LAUGH comes from the gate as Fatin and Fatima ente Ms. Hussa moves towards them.
All right girls, you are just behind the gate, don't laugh so loudly. Women's voices shouldn't carry outside the door! Fatin smiles and nudges Fatima. They giggle but act polit
Sorry, Ms. Hussa.
It won’t happen again. Wajda seizes the opportunity to try to sneak past but--  12 13 14

Wajda! Caught! Wajda stops, turns to face her. MS. HUSSA (CONT’D) (with malicious enjoyment) Where is your head cover? Are you coming to school unveiled?! And who put those awful clips in your hair? The girls all stop talking and giggle at her, except for Fatin and Fatima who watch sympathetically. Wajda looks down in frustration at her wet veil.
The midday sun burns directly above Wajda as she stands i the corner of the schoolyard, punished.

Wajda's sneakers stand out from all the other girls in pl black shoes, leaving school. Her eyes then catch colorful majestic feet as a group of boys pedal by on their bicycl They kick up dust and laugh, gliding past. Wajda watches forlornly as they disappear around the corner. Wajda continues walking, throwing the stone her Father ga her at various targets. She misses a few times and then finally hears a “Ping” as it hits its first mark: A SHINY

Somehow perched above the other side of a fence. She stares at it, intrigued, for several seconds, as it s to float on the other side of the fence. She picks up her black stone and entranced, her eyes follow this vision. Suddenly it begins to move across the top of the fence, u it comes to the end, where Wajda sees that it’s resting o the top of a moving truck. Her heart locks on it and with even thinking, she runs after the bicycle as it disappear down the next block.

location: STREET IN FRONT OF THE TOY SHOP

text: Wajda’s feet race, her eyes like steel and she finally catches up to the truck now parked in front of a toy shop  15 10. Men unload boxes and bicycles wrapped in plastic bags. Sh cranes her neck. Where is the green one? As Wajda moves forward she hears a SPLASH! She looks down She's standing in a stream of water. She moves to the sid As the truck pulls away the TOY SHOP OWNER goes into the and brings out THE BICYCLE. He puts it on display in the front, out in the sun. He takes a sign from his clipboard writes, "Only 500 Riyals," and places it on the handlebar He goes back inside the store and puts an "Talal Maddah" record on an old record player, glancing at this strange little girl still standing outside his door. Her eye then shift to the sign and the price as the MUSIC drifts out of the store.

Wajda counts the small wad of money she made at school to and stuffs it back into her pocket in frustration. She ta out the black stone from her pocket and throws it across field at a coke bottle. A group of WORKERS yell suggestiv insults at her.

Nice throw! Come up and play with us! Let me touch those little apples. Wajda freezes and pretends she didn't hear him. They laugh vulgarly at her. As she hurries towards the ro Abdullah appears and picks it up. He throws it far across lot, knocking another coke bottle out of its place. Wajda relaxes, relieved to see him, but then acts upset a she runs and picks up the stone. She picks up another one throws it back towards him.

Take this! And stop following me. I don't want to play with you any more. They made me stand up all day at school in the sun for not having a veil today. The rock falls short of Abdullah's feet. He looks at Wajd ashamed. Wajda puts her stone in her pocket, glaring at h He picks up the rock and runs to his bicycle and pulls ou package.  11.

Here, I got you this. Wajda looks at him, walks over and takes the package. She opens it and unfurls a new black veil with a yellow flowe made of beads on the corner. She acts defiant as she puts in her bag.
This doesn't make us even, you know. We'll get even when we race. I‘1l have my new bicycle very soon.
What? Girls can't have bicycles!

Then I guess it will be that much more embarrassing for you when I beat you! Wajda walks away in a huff. Abdullah looks at the stone s threw at him and stuffs it in his pocket. Abdullah rides away on his bicycle as a small pick-up tru passes by causing a huge cloud of dust over Abdullah. Waj looks back and laughs. The CONTRACTOR gets out of his car and heads towards the workers. He looks at Abdullah.
Hey, you, go away little boy! Abdullah is upset. The Contractor goes over to the worker
All day and only one pillar? 5 men working and I get only one pillar? He slaps one of them on his neck.
Go to car go.. We have to finish working on the other building. He stuffs the workers onto the back of the truck. Some of workers put wet towels on their heads to avoid the unbear heat.  16 17 18 12.

Wajda’s sneakers kick up small clouds of dust as she head home. Green bushes have just been planted on the side of road. She leans over and smells them. She smiles and pick the leaves off, one by one.

Wajda sits at her desk with her money out in front of her The green leaves are now sorted into small plastic bags t the side. She writes "500 Riyals" on a piece of paper and draws a chart underneath. She sorts the notes and counts them.

10 riyals, 15 riyals, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25 riyals. She writes "25 Riyals" on the chart. Then Wajda sits on t floor with her foot extended and wraps strings around her toe making woven bracelets. She checks a list of girls' n and football teams. She hears the DOOR opening and goes to meet her Mother.

Wajda's Mother's face is puffy and red. She falls down on couch exhausted, removes her veil and fans herself with i Her hair loks messy but full of ribbons and curls. Wajda turns on the air conditioner, grinning. Her Mother looks at her as she struggles to lift herself from the co
I don't like this look. What are you up to?
(excited) I'm going to buy a bicycle to race Abdullah Al Hanofi!
Three hours in the car without AC! I swear this commute is going to kill me and you tell me bicycle? She takes off her shoes and black socks, rubbing her feet  19 20 13.

Absolutely forget about getting a bicycle. Have you ever seen any girl riding a bicycle? (pause) I'd rather sell fruit down at the hospital than go on this hideous trip every day! Wajda makes a face and stomps off to her room. Her Mother goes to her bedroom and picks up a man's dirty blue unifo from the floor.
Wajda hurries off through the gate of a house.

location: LIVING ROOM OF WAJDA'S GRANDMOTHER'S HOUSE

text: She enters and finds her GRANDMOTHER, an overweight woman her 60's, watching TV, the remote in her hand.
(surprised) Wajda! What are you doing here so early? Wajda smiles. She goes up and kisses her forehead.

Good morning, Grandmother. Hope you are doing well today. Look what I got you! Wajda gives her a plastic bag filled with green leaves. S then opens her abbayah, exposing a navy-blue vest on top her gray uniform. She smiles wider.
See, Grandmother, I'm wearing the vest you made me.

(smiling but suspicious) It's nice of you to think of me this early in the morning! She looks happily at the vest and smells the leaves. She pulls her braided hair from her veil and replaces the withering leaves with the fresh ones Wajda brought.  21 14.

(reluctantly) Only 10 riyals! I brought some for your friend Um Khalid too! The Grandmother, twisting her lips in annoyance, slips he feet into her shoes, sighs, lifts herself slowly out of h chair and walks toward the next room.
Did your Mother send you? She struggles to get herself down a small step. Wajda loo at her sympathetically and helps her. Her Grandmother gen pats Wadja's back.
No, Grandma! I'm trying to save some money.. to buy a nice abbayah.

I don't know what to do with you or your Father. He’s always nagging me, "Should I take a second wife? I need a son." I tell him, "Go home to your wife and daughter and leave me alone," but he keeps coming here with a list of families I have to call for brides. The Grandmother gets her wallet and gives Wajda 10 riyals GRANDMOTHER (CONT’D) He can't even buy an abbayah for his daughter. Where would he get a dowry for a second wife?
Thanks, Grandma! Wajda runs out, avoiding looking at her Grandmother.

location: INSIDE THE FRONT GATE OF THE SCHOOL

text: Wajda walks past Ms. Hussa, tea-cup in hand, bored, watch the crowd of girls flow through the gate. Noura approaches Ms. Hussa coyly. She gathers up her cour and holds out a single flower with a note attached.
(sweetly) This is for you.  22 23 15. Wajda watches from the corner of her eye. Ms. Hussa looks questionably at Noura, takes the flower and reads the not

Thank you for your feelings, but you know you are not supposed to bring flowers to school. Noura reddens. Ms. Hussa gives her back the flower then h over to the gate, not noticing the note falling to the ground. Wajda rushes over, picks the note up, stealthily looks at laughs, sticks it in her vest pocket and hurries inside. INT. CLASSROOM — DAY 22 Wajda enters. One girl cleans the blackboard while others copy each other's homework.
(to another girl) Change the sentence a little, she will know you copied it! (noticing Wajda) Here comes the salesgirl!
Hey Wajda, did you finish the bracelets?
Not all. I have only 10. You have to pay 2 riyals extra. It's a lot of work! The girls gather as she hands out bracelets and collects money.
Quickly, I have to go!
Wajda is playing on the hopscotch grid. Noura raises her and looks off into the distance.
We need to go inside! Men are watching us!  16. All the girls look to where Noura is pointing. Wajda can barely make out a group of construction workers atop a building in the distance.
They're so far away; they can't see us from there.
If you can see them, they can see you. Come on, all good girls are going inside. She smirks at Wajda as the girls all follow her in. Shame Wajda thinks, then smiles and calls out.

Hey Noura! (pulls out the note) "I love you, Ms. Hussa. You are like the moon, my dream, my eyes, and my heart!" Ha Ha! Noura looks furiously at Wajda who waves the note in the making kissing noises. She puts the note into her vest po and tosses a rock onto the hop-scotch grid. Noura storms inside. Wajda looks up to see Fatin and Fatima pass by looking at magazine while walking towards the back of the school.
Hey, you shouldn't be outside, men can see you!

(sarcastically) Men are watching? What a scandal! They'll tell everyone they saw Wajda al Safan playing provocatively in the schoolyard. They can't miss you, especially in that sexy vest of yours. She and Fatima smile and head over to Wajda.
So, what's the latest mix?
(excited, like a salesman) It's got everything, "Bink, get the barty start..."  17.
(laughing) "Party."
Whatever, "party." 10 riyals.

(laughing) You little devil, I don't know where you get this music from. I'll get one later for sure. Hey, what about bracelets? Look at this gorgeous creature. (holds up a picture of a football player) I want a bracelet of his team- Al Hilal.
(inspecting the picture) No problem, I'll make you a special one for tomorrow, but 10 riyals.
(patting her head) Okay, tomorrow then, little hustler.
(smiling, pulling her head away ) Don't mess my hair! And hey, you're not supposed to bring magazines to school! Ms. Hussa will kill you.

Look who's talking! Your bag is a 24 hour convenience store. The three laugh and Wajda continues playing. Fatin and Fa sit just past the corner of the building. They pull out n polish from their pockets and start painting their toenai blue, the magazine open next to them. Wajda stops halfway through a leap on the hopscotch grid, left foot still elevated, as she sees Ms. Hussa approach. The girls quickly rush inside, dropping the nail polish bottle on the bench. Ms. Hussa turns to find Wajda alone, staring at her.  24 25 18.

What are you doing there? Go to your class right now or you'll be punished! Wajda stares down at the ground and quickly follows Ms. H into the building. She sees the bottle of blue nail polis scoops it up and hurries off.

location: INSIDE THE FRONT GATE OF THE SCHOOL

text: Ms. Hussa stands in front of the gate, examining the girl they pass. She stops one girl with a "Titanic" backpack.
Wajda’s about to leave when an older girl, ABER, pulls he aside and whispers to her.
Can you take this paper out to my brother?
(suspiciously) What is this?
Shh! It’s a.. permission slip to pick me up from school. Wajda glances over at Ms. Hussa, concerned.
(whispering, but adamant) I'll give you 10 riyals! Wajda looks back at Ms. Hussa, then at Abeer.
Abeer sighs, gives her some money and the note.
He's outside on the corner ina pickup truck. Wajda goes out cautiously, trying to act casual.  26 27 19.

location: INSIDE THE FRONT GATE OF THE SCHOOL

text: Ms. Hussa scolds the backpack girl, who anxiously watches bus fill up.
«And change your bag, images are forbidden! Ms. Hussa gate. She tries Ms. Hussa pulls her
(running towards the bus) Okay, okay, Inshallah. I've got to catch the bus! turns just as Wajda’s about to leave through the

Wajda! to hide the paper in her bag and heads over. pauses, looks at Wajda, then over to Abeer. Abeer veil quickly over her face and turns away. Ms. Hussa squints down at Wajda, studying her. She hands MS. HUSSA (CONT’D) Come with an abbayah like this tomorrow or we will reserve your place in the sun for you. Here. Wajda a pamphlet with a picture of a black figure on the front. Wajda takes it and hurries off.
Wajda passes by the school bus, overflowing with girls, a sees a handsome YOUNG MAN, (20's), by a pickup truck, waiting.
Are you Abeer's brother?
(smiling) Yeah sure, I'm her brother. Have you got the paper?
(holding it out) Yeah, she said you'd give me 20 riyals to deliver it.  28 20.
(skeptically) Really? Hmmm.
(haughtily) You don't look like her brother!
(laughing) Okay, okay here's 20. Wajda takes the money and sniffs it, making a funny face.
Even your money reeks of perfume! I'll have to wash it. He tries to suppress a smile, dismisses her with a wave, gets in his car. He drives around in front of the gate.
Abeer Rassi come to the gate. Your ride is here to pick you up.

location: STREET IN FRONT OF THE TOY SHOP

text: Wajda sees the green bicycle glimmering in the afternoon and stops in awe. As The Owner comes out, Wajda licks her finger and rubs a "X" on the bicycle, claiming it. Her face beams with happiness.

(indicating her “X"”) Don't sell this one. I reserved it! The Owner uses his sleeve to rub the bicycle clean where touched it. He looks down at her with a glimmer in his eyes. THE CALL FOR DHUHUR PRAYER interrupts the moment. He cove his goods with a big black blanket. Wajda watches as the blanket falls over her bicycle.  29 30 21.

Abdullah is amongst A CROWD OF MEN heading to pray at the mosque by the toy shop along with HIS FATHER and mustache UNCLE. As Wajda sees him she turns away and hides the distinguishing yellow flower on her veil under her abbaya As she turns back Abdullah sees her in the crowd. They lo at each other. She gestures with her eyes to the handle o the green bicycle showing underneath the blanket. Abdullah rubs his fingers together to show that it will t money to buy it. Wajda takes out twenty riyals from her pocket and waves it defiantly at him. She turns her head proudly and struts off. INT. WAJDA'S PARENTS’ ROOM - NIGHT 30 Wajda’s on her Mother's bed, legs on the headboard, her toenails now painted blue. Her Mother sits in front of th mirror straightening her hair and singing beautifully.
I'll write you a love letter. Tell you how much I miss you... She takes another lock of hair and runs the iron over it.
I wish I could cut my hair shorter like Lubna Abdul Aziz.
Do it.

Your Father loves my long hair. (singing) I'll write you a love letter. Tell you how much I miss you... She takes out a bandana to wrap her hair and sees a new t of lipstick in front of her. The Mother looks at Wajda in the mirror with a touched sm Wajda sees her Mother smiling and turns away shyly. Her Mother applies the lipstick.
I'd thank you for this but I'm afraid to ask where you got the money. Did you ask your Grandmother for it?  31 32 22.
I sold her stuff! It's not charity!
I don't want you going over there! Your Father finishes his shift early tomorrow night. What should we cook? Margoog?
I hate margoog. And is he going to give me my allowance this month or is he going to skip it again?
(ironing her hair) Your Father loves margoog. We'll cook it for him.

Cook me kapsa! He’s paying the second wife's dowry off with my allowance! Wajda's Mother stops ironing, her body language becomes s and tense. Wajda reddens, Her Mother remains silent, ties the bandan into place, rises, and exits to the kitchen.
As Wajda she sees Ms. Hussa at the end of the hall, glari intensely at her.

An avalanche of items comes pouring out of Wajda's backpa onto the desk as Ms. Hussa shakes out its contents. Wajda sits nervously in a chair. The rock her Father gave her tumbles off the desk and onto the floor next to her. Ms. Hussa shakes her head as she goes through the bracele cassettes, schoolbooks, notebooks and candy bars. She pic up one of the tapes and relaxes back into her chair.  23.

(Authoritatively) Tapes full of love songs, bracelets, all of this... You know are not allowed in school! She opens a folder, signing papers as she talks. MS. HUSSA (CONT’D) Abeer was always a good girl. Do you know how she ended up getting picked up with a strange boy by the religious police? Wajda remains silent, trying not to fidget. MS. HUSSA (CONT’D) Thank God they found someone to marry her off to, it's not like her family will let her come back to school after this. Ms. Hussa stops signing, sits back in her chair and stare Wajda, who looks back at her nervously. MS. HUSSA (CONT’D) So, did you arrange this whole rendezvous for Abeer and her lover?
(defensively) No, I didn't!

Don’t lie. I know you took part in this. I just don’t know how. What shall we do with you now? Expel you? Suddenly her secretary, MS. JAMILA, enters the room. Ms. Hussa stops and looks at the folder in her hand. Wajda looks down and notices her black stone. She quickly pockets it. MS. HUSSA (CONT’D) (To Ms. Jamila) Just a moment please. (To Wajda) You may go back to your class. We'll finish this matter later. Wajda takes her notebooks off of the desk and puts them slowly back into her backpack. She walks towards the door  24. MS. HUSSA (CONT’D) And Wajda, wear normal black shoes like all the other girls!
Wajda stands outside and listens.
Call Wajda's Mother and see if she can come in for a meeting tomorrow. We have to decide once and for all, what to do about that girl. Wajda becomes terrified. MS. HUSSA (CONT’D) Now what is this?
The proposal for the Koran competition in the religion club. We just need your signature to request the prize money awards. $800 riyals. Wajda’s ears perk up at the amount of money. Thinks...

At least we have something good to show the superintendant. Thank God not all the girls are delinquents. All right, let’s get started on it. Wajda’s heart races. She pulls together all her courage a knocks on Ms. Hussa's door.
Ms. Hussa takes a deep breath, and looks at Wajda, who nervously crosses her feet to cover her black high tops.
I thought about what you said. I was wrong and am ready to change. I would like to join the religious club.
(incredulous ) You are becoming a Shiekha all of a sudden?  35 25.
Maybe I'll learn something. You know.. to put me on the righteous path. Ms. Hussa peers at her, suspiciously.
I will call your Mother tomorrow and speak to her about this. If we agree, it’s your last chance.
Wajda's Mother makes margoog, working handfuls of dough between her hands while she sings. Wajda cuts the dough a the Mother puts some in the pan.
I'll write you a love letter. Tell you how much I miss you...
Don't you wish you were a singer? You sing so well! Wajda's Mother feigns shock.
Never! I seek refuge to God from what you said! Woman's voices shouldn't carry beyond the front door. Her Mother continues singing, now performing dramatically
I'll write you a love letter; Tells you how much I miss you. Explains my pain in your absence. Wajda joins her Mother in singing.
Why did you leave? You forgot our nights? I'll write you a love letter... Wajda and her Mother laugh together. After a moment...  36 26.
So I've saved up 87 riyals already and I only need 413 to get the bicyc--
(annoyed) Ouuuff! Again! We closed this subject! You are not getting a bicycle. It is haram! They stand in silence while they cook idly. Wajda sighs a after a moment smiles and looks away casually.
They said I need to wear the full abbayah to school from now on. I also registered in the religious studies club. The Mother smiles reluctantly.
Wow, wearing the full abbayah now, religious study, someone has become a woman, maybe we will marry you off!

Come with me. INT. WAJDA'S PARENTS’ ROOM - NIGHT 36 The Mother pulls out an abbayah from the cabinet and hand to Wajda.

Try this. (laughing) ) It might be long for you. Carry it like this: Her Mother bunches her dress up in her hands and walks ar the room as if she were wearing high heels. Wajda copies exaggerated movements.  37 38 27.

(suppressing a smile) Shame on you, talking like this. We don't know, it could have been a thief. They burst into laughter together. Wajda puts on the abba and the veil while her Mother looks out the window.
Your Uncle's wedding is coming up, you know. I have to buy something really nice so all the other women know what they’re up against. Wajda turns to her Mother, all in black. The phone RINGS.
Her Mother talks on the phone while checking the margoog.
I'm so sorry, Leila. Iqbal our driver is so rude. He shouted at poor Aiesha today. Aiesha who never raises her voice! She cried the whole three hours on the way home.
Wajda counts her money. The abbayah is on the bed. She go to the list with "500 Riyals" written at the top, crosses "25 Riyals" and counts and sorts the banknotes she has.
83, 84, 85, 86...87 riyals. She writes "87 riyals" on the chart.  39 40 28.
Leila, dear, we're completely full. Honestly, you'd be better off with another driver. Wajda kisses the money with an enthusiastic "smack" and p it in the drawer.

Really? Abeer? Daughter of Mariam? How did she even end up in a car with him? Who is he? Of course, he’s a playboy like his Father. (laughs ) You have to admit, he is good looking. Wajda sits up on the edge of the chair, concerned.
Religious police? Mariam must be dying! They should have married her off a long time ago. Pretty girls are like curses. They hear the front door open and someone come in.
I have to go, our Father has just come. Keep me in the loop on this Abeer scandal. Yalla bye. She quickly hangs up, removes her bandana and fixes her h
Wajda sits in her room waiting and looking concerned. Her Mother peeks in.
Go and say hello to your Father as I prepare his dinner. What's wrong? Are you okay? Don't worry we won't marry you off... (smiling) Not just yet!  4l 29.

Her Father sits on the floor playing a video game on the His gutra and Ogal are folded up next to him with a brand cell phone on top. A string of light blue prayer beads ar next to him as well. She collapses casually onto the co
I'm losing, I should have stayed with my usual fighter. On the screen a warrior rests, haggard from the fight.
(teasing) So is that a real certificate or a fake one like you made last year?
What?! I'm great at math, do you want to hear... (mispronouncing it) pythagoreium’s theory? It's a miracle of God, all the things come out the same!
Sounds like you know what you're talking about. He laughs and continues playing. She waits a moment, then
I'm saving to buy a bicycle! Her Father is so focused on his game he doesn’t hear her. loses and the MUSIC announces the end of the match. He le back.

Oh, where is the margoog? Didn't your Mother finish cooking? Wajda watches him as he runs his prayer beads idly betwee his fingers. Her Mother enters and sets dishes on a littl mat on the floor just beside the Father who lights up at presence. She is all dressed up, looking her best.  42 43 30.
Wajda, who is this movie star who just entered? Look at this hair, a beautiful black waterfall of silk! The Mother tosses back her hair, pleased, but hiding it.

Cut it out! (teasing, yet bitter) A movie star huh? Then why is your Mother checking all over town for available women for you? The Father looks up and their eyes meet with pained looks reaches out and puts his hand on hers. She pauses for a second and looks at him tenderly. She playfully pulls her hand away and tosses her hair over her shoulder. He bursts into a charming laugh and pulls her towards him Wajda watches them together, happily.
I'm not sure she's working that hard! Sit and play with me! She laughs seductively while she frees herself and contin setting up the plates.
Let me play! I'll take the old guy! Prepare to die! She jumps off the couch while the Father is laughing.
Wajda sits in class, looking out the doorway into the corridor. Suddenly she sees her Mother walking with Ms Hu to her office and goes rigid. Her Mother nervously fixes her hair and adjusts her blous

text: Frazzled, Wajda walks quickly home staring straight ahead She looks up and sees the bicycle in front of the shop. The Toy Shop Owner sits, drinking tea with ANOTHER MAN. A BEARDED MAN approaches. The other man puts down his tea cup and quickly exits.  44 45 46 31. The Owner gets up to walk into the store with the Bearded Man. The owner is trying to be cordial with him. The man breaks one of the toys. Wajda hurries off. She hears the man shouting.
No idols! Don't you fear God?
The Mother cleans a pile of dishes from the previous nigh One slips off her shaking hands and falls to the ground. leans on the edge of the sink and yells loudly.
All this for a bicycle that you'll never have as long as I'm alive. Do you think I'll wait around until you get expelled?!!
Wajda covers her ears as her Mother breaks another dish - purpose this time. Wajda turns on the radio to a ROCK SON

And turn off that damn radio and those evil songs! You're no better than Abeer. She's staying home and her parents are marrying her off. And that is what we'll do with you too! There's no school for you tomorrow! Wajda turns it off and lies down, looking at her shoes.
Wajda's Mother paces, talking on the phone, agitated.

I know Iqbal, but my daughter had a problem at school. I didn't have time to tell you. You're paid for the trip whether I am there or not. Don't come tomorrow. (pause) How dare you speak to me that way? (MORE )
Do you think you are the only driver in town?.. Fine! I'll find someone else! She SLAMS the phone down hard and leans back into the cou

Wajda sits on her bed with her knee to her chin, coloring the white toe and sole of her shoe with a black marker. S pulls out the colored laces and sadly replaces them with black twine from her bracelets. We hear the door opening and her Father comes in. Wajda t to listen.
Really? I should pay for it? Why can’t you pay for something for once?
What about your transportation allowance? You should use it instead of doing that group where you all pool your money. Wajda puts down her shoes and leans her head on the door.
Yeah, and what about the dowry money, you handsome groom?

Do you think I want to support two families? I'm the joke of the town. Are you going to give me a son? We both know that is not going to happen. (frustrated) Forget it, and don't count on me coming next week at all!

(yelling after him) I don't care! Go to your mother’s house to discuss potential brides all night! A door SLAMS, then only silence. Wajda's eyes fall on the chart she made to map out her savings for the bicycle.  48 49 50 33.
As Wajda prepares to leave for school she looks through t half open door of her Mother's room. Her Mother’s talking the phone, her hair a mess, looking exhausted.

Can't you count it as emergency leave? I still have some days. You know I've been working hard, covering for everyone. I'll open up for the entire month if I have to. Okay, thank you, see you tomorrow. She hangs up, distraught then sees Wajda through the door
Where do you think you're going? Didn't you hear me yesterday?
I sorted everything out with Ms. Hussa!
Back to your room and don't come out. I don't want to see you today at all, I don't want to hear a peep from you - nothing!
Aren't you going to work today?
(sarcastic) No darling, I'm staying here to watch over you. Happy? The Mother gets into bed and rolls over, covering herself with the blanket.

Wajda turns on the RADIO and lowers the volume until it’s barely audible. She looks through her doorway at the hous keys hanging by the front door. She can see her Mother on couch, smoking, watching TV, completely depressed.
Wajda sneaks past her Mother to the stairwell to the roof  51 52 53 34.

Wajda carefully lowers herself down a pipe along the side the house. She slips and her black rock falls from her po onto the ground. Through the window she sees her Mother c herself and rush over. She pulls herself against the wall freezes. The Mother looks out, cautiously. Wajda holds on the pipe, holding her breath. Her Mother finally returns the couch and Wajda lowers herself down. She opens the gate, takes gum out of her mouth and sticks into the lock so it doesn't close completely.
Wajda waits by the boys' school, hiding behind a wall, un Abdullah finally arrives on his bicycle. Wajda throws a s next to him and he looks over, surprised to see her.
Do you know how to go to Adira?
Wajda rides on the back of Abdullah's bicycle as he pedal them along. As they pass the toy shop she sees the green bicycle glimmer in the distance. His feet spin the pedals
You have to get off once we see someone on the road. I don't want people to talk about me. And cover your face, I'll say you're my sister!
No one will believe you, I'm too good looking to be related to you!
Yeah right. And isn't the principal going to call your Mother for skipping school like this?

I’m taking a personal day. They approach a busy road. Wajda gets off and walks along him.  35. They arrive to an older part of the town where foreign workers pass by. AN INDIAN MAN sits in front of a house, smoking. Wajda approaches him, cautiously.
Hey, do you know where Iqbal the driver lives?

Do you know how many "Iqbal" drivers there are around here, little girl? Wajda shrugs. They continue searching the area, from one street to the other. Wajda suddenly sees the minibus with taped headlights parked next to a dilapidated house. She moves closer and looks into the car. She sees the picture the little girl placed on the dashboard. She motions for Abdullah to knock at the door, but he sha his head and stands behind his bicycle.
It’s your war!

Fine! Wajda frowns at him and knocks at the door. She waits sev moments and looks over at Abdullah, who looks away, asham She knocks again and the door slowly opens. Iqbal stumbles out, rubs sleep from his eyes and sees Waj
You! What do you want?
You can't do this! You..you.. Wajda is overtaken by emotion and cannot speak. Iqbal dismisses her and tries to close the door. Suddenly Abdul puts his foot inside.
(assertively) Where is your Iqamah (residency card)? Iqbal looks at him threateningly, enraged.
Go away!  54 36.

(more assertively) It is a good job, there are no problems. Just go back to it and we'll all forget about this incident. Do you know who my Uncle is? The one with the moustache? Have you seen his election posters? I'm sure he'd be interested to look further into your legal status. Abdullah holds his ground as Wajda folds her arms behind looking at Iqbal challengingly.
Wajda laughs hard as she runs after Abdullah, riding ahea his bicycle. Wajda mimics him.
“Don't you know my Uncle? With the giant mustache?” Abdullah laughs as he dismounts.
He knew him, right? That mustache is a registered trademark! Abdullah directs her attention to a house busy with MEN coming in and out. He directs her away from the scene.
Their son put stuff around his waist that blows up and died. Boom! He acts out pulling a cord and makes an explosive noise.
He's crazy! That must have hurt.
No, if you die for God, it's like a prick of a needle, and then you fly up and you have seventy women!
Really? She acts out a big explosion.  55 56 57 37.
Boom! Seventy bicycles! Abdullah leans his bicycle against the wall and runs towa a small grocery store. He shouts back to her.
It doesn't work that way. Stay with the bicycle so no one steals it. Wajda leans on it and strikes a pose ala Marlon Brando in "The Wild One.”
Wajda looks through the window at her Mother, lying on th couch. As soon as she gets up, Wajda ducks down quickly. waits for her Mother to go to the bathroom and then sneak inside.
Wajda lies on her bed, exhausted. She looks over at her savings chart and sorts her money again.
60, 70, 80, 85, 86, 87 riyals.. Her Mother pokes her head inside and Wajda shoves the mon under her pillow, feigning innocence and repentance.
Had enough? Wajda nods.
Tomorrow you can return to school, but you are joining that religious club, like you told Ms. Hussa.
Wajda's black converses dangle above the floor while she at a row of desks with twenty other girls. On the blackbo the KORAN TEACHER writes "The Religious Club: Agenda" the turns to the class.  38.
Let's compile all the stories we know about torment in the grave and make a pamphlet for the whole school. Any ideas?

(raising her hand) I want to tell the story of the giant snake from Hell that was sent to torture the girl that did not pray after she died. Wadja is busy drawing a picture of a bicycle when she hea Ms. Hussa’s high heels approach. Behind Wajda, Yasmine whispers to Noura, giggling.
There was a thief at Ms. Hussa's house...
It was her lover, not a thief! Her Father thought it was a thief and called the police! A conservative older girl, SALMA, shushes them.
If she said it was a thief, then it was a thief.

(rolling her eyes) Of course you would think that, Salma. The only man that would ever speak to you would have to be a thief. Salma looks down, eyes watering. The girls giggle then compose themselves as Ms. Hussa enters.

Girls, Ms. Hussa is here to explain the Koranic competition rules. It's only five weeks away. I'll pass around a sign up sheet. The teacher hands out the sheet as Wajda tuns the page to hide the bicycle drawing. Ms. Hussa glances at Wajda, the the class.  58 59 39.

First, we've increased the amount for the prize. It is now 1,000 instead of 800 riyals. You'll have to learn all the long suras (the first 4 chapters of the Koran). Wajda raises her eyebrows. She flips through the Koran on her desk and measures the amount of paper she would have learn. MS. HUSSA (CONT’D) The competition is two parts: you'll to study the associated vocabulary along with the reasons why the verses were descended from heaven. You also have to learn the verses and the proper recitation. The correct tone, rhythm and pacing are very important. Wajda sneaks a look at her bicycle drawing and watches th sign up sheet as it passes from one girl to another, nervously. Salma is the first to sign up followed by Nour and then Yasmine... The sheet finally comes to her and Wajda scribbles her na Noura raises an eyebrow and looks to Yasmine as Wajda smu brings it up, hands it to intrigued Ms. Hussa and smiles.

text: Walking home from school, Wajda stops, checks out the bic and then walks inside with determination.

Do you know they invented a new thing called a tape player?
Do you plan on buying anything?

How would I know? People need to browse, don't they?  60 61 40. Nonchalantly, she walks around in the aisles pretending t look at other toys. Her eyes stay focused on the bicycle section. Can you even ride one?

Can you put this picture on a mug? The picture shows a veiled woman holding a smiling baby g

Hey, where's your bicycle? I thought you're getting the nice green one! HA!
(furious) I will, I have a plan.

(laughing) I'm sure you do, but it doesn't seem to be working. As he pedals away, the shopkeeper comes out and hands Waj the mug. He la and tries to pedal away, but is weighed down by the light Wajda closes in on him, and pulls him down to the ground grabbing the string of lights over his shoulder.

(breathing heavily) I just signed up for a Koranic recitation competition. I'll get a thousand riyals by the end of the semester. I'll buy a bicycle anda helmet like people on TV. I will race you and win!
Yeah.. Race me and win.. In your dreams, little girl! He laughs again, gets back on the bicycle and pedals off.
(yells) I caught you didn't I?
I let you catch me!

57, 58, 59, 60, 61...62 riyals.  63 64 42. She sighs, picks up the mug, and stares at the picture on

She smiles, flirtatious

MOTHER (0.S.)(CONT’D) I collected the money from the other girls for you, Leila. It’s been with me for sometime now. Aren't you coming to take it?.. Really! Go see who it is.
Wajda opens the door and sees Abdullah, holding a rolled extension cord over his shoulder. They stare at each othe a confrontational way. Wajda acts annoyed.
What do you want?  43.
My Uncle wants me to string up these lights all the way down the street. Can I attach them to your roof? And by the way you never said thank you!
Use the neighbors; we don't care about your Uncle or his mustache. Thanks for what?

(annoyed) They don't have a pole to hang them on. Yours is the only roof that will work. "Thanks" for taking you all the way to Adira and fixing the driver situation. He’s taking your Mother again, right?
(looking at his bicycle) Hold on. She slams the door and runs to her Mother's room.

(yelling through the door) Hey Mother! Abdulla Al Noufi wants to use our roof to string up lights for the election so his Uncle with the mustache will win. Her Mother opens the door, holding the mug, smiling at Wa Wajda smiles back upon seeing the mug.

Abdullah stands, impatiently. Wajda comes back, thinks.  67

(casually) I'll let you onto the roof if you bring your bicycle. They look at each other defiantly across the doorway. They both turn as a minibus full of foreign, mostly Filip nurses stops in front of their building. A fully covered Saudi woman, LEILA, jumps out. The minibus waits, idling. Leila hurries up the stairs towards Wajda. She accidental bumps into Abdullah as he tries to move out of the way.
Hey Wajda, it's me Leila. She removes her veil and exposes her face, smiling.
You look so grown up and cute! Wajda glances at Abdullah, making sure he heard the compliment. He gets on his bicycle and pedals away.
Can you call your Mother? The bus is waiting. Just then her Mother appears behind her. She stands just behind the front gate, hiding from strangers.
You traitor! I can't believe you're working so close to my house without even telling me!

(laughing) Working at the hospital is great. It pays more, they provide transportation and I don't have to endure someone like Iqbal for three hours every day! Both women laugh. Wajda's Mother hands Leila the money.
Thank you, dear. When is your turn?  45.
Next month. I want to buy a nice dress for her Uncle's engagement. She gestures at Wajda, kicking a rock on the ground.
All the other potential wives will be attending his brother's wedding as well.
God be with the one he chooses-- You might rip her heart out that night! Wajda laughs and the Mother glares at her.
Is he going to drive you to the wedding so he sees you before you go to the women's section?
No, his Mother is taking us ina cab! The minivan HONKS.
Ugh. I have to go. Oh before I forget, they're hiring at the hospital. Think about it. It’s closer and we can chat all day!
(rolls her eyes) My husband would kill me. He's so jealous. He couldn't stand the thought of other men looking at me!
(laughing) Cut it out! You blame everything on him. If you change your mind, call me! I'll keep an application at reception for you. As she leaves, the Mother watches Leila, enviously.  68 46.

Wajda's black colored shoes sit in a pile with all of the others by the door. The girls sit on the floor in a circl Wajda sits patiently, focused on the teacher. The Koran Teacher has Salma pass out a copy to each stude from a small shelf in the corner of the room.

Now girls let's start our program. But before we start, I know some of you may have gotten your period, so you are not allowed to touch the Koran. Some of the girls GIGGLE. Yasmine flips the pages, using a Kleenex. The teacher loo at Wajda, sarcastically. KORAN TEACHER (CONT’D) Let's start with the new face in our group - Wajda. Start with Surat al Nisa, from ayat 59. Wajda slowly opens the book, looks at the pages, and look the teacher. The teacher looks at her sternly.
(reading in broken pacing) O you who have believed, obey Allah and obey the Messenger and those in authority among you. And if you disagree over anything...
(correcting her) «refer it to Allah and the Messenger...
(repeating the teacher) ...-Refer it to Allah and the Messenger, if you should believe in Allah and the Last Day. That is the best [way] and best in result...  69 47.
(holding out her hand) Stop, please. Noura, continue.
(in perfect harmony) ...refer it to Allah and the Messenger, if you should believe in Allah and the Last Day. That is the best [way] and best in result
Beautiful as always, Noura. Wajda looks at Noura with extreme envy.
Fatin and Fatima once again look at a football magazine a take off their shoes to paint their toenails.

Where is the blue nail polish? I hid it under there the other day. Wajda approaches but ducks back just as Ms. Hussa swoops on the two girls. Fatin and Fatima cover their feet, looking panicked. They push the magazine under each other's clothes.

What are you doing here? Why were your hands under her skirt? The girls freeze in their tracks. Wajda stands motionless watching. MS. HUSSA (CONT’D) This is all we need at our school: two girls hiding in the back yard, putting their hands all over each other! Tell me what that means? The girls recoil from each other, mortified. MS. HUSSA (CONT’D) “Sorry” isn’t going to cut it this time. In my office. Now!  70 71 72 48.

Wajda sees Fatin and Fatima leaving the school, extremely upset. They pull their veils down covering their angry fa Crowds of girls bump past Wajda, all wearing black abbaya Wajda wearily puts on hers as well.
Wajda heads straight to the bicycle and runs her hand ove it. She sees that it is locked down with a chain. The Own comes out with a box.
What are you doing? Still browsing?
No. I know what I’m here to get. She picks up the "Learn the Koran the Easy way" game whil the owner restocks the shelves, watching her.
How much?
Only 80 riyals.. Cheaper than a bicycle.
(in a polite tone) How about 62?

(while he works) With all the people shouting? “Awesome” indeed. My Uncle now listens to the Koran radio station. He will speak on the channel now. They have all those famous Koran readers. “It makes your heart melt,” my Uncle says.

(her hand over her heart) He should hear my Mother sing! She should have a channel of her own. Wajda leans over against the railing to push herself alon the bicycle. She idly switches a broken bare light-bulb o and off on the side wall.
Stop, you'll burn it out!
It doesn't work anyway. She looks down at the campaign tent.
Why does your Uncle look different now? In the poster the Uncle has shaved his mustache and has g out a big beard.
Didn't you hear? Men shouldn't shave their beards! It is haram! What do they teach you at school?

(challengingly) I don’t know. “Women’s stuff.” Our “special days of the month”... She bursts into fits of laughter as Abdullah, embarrassed goes back to work. Wajda balances awkwardly on the bicycl and RINGS the little bell.  73 50.
(smiling while he works) Everyone in the neighborhood will hear you ringing that bell.
Who cares? Look, I'm a natural. She swerves and falls hard. Abdullah giggles.
Yeah right. All that fuss for a bicycle and you don't even know how to ride?
How would I? Where would I ride a bicycle? She makes a face as Abdullah jumps up and stands behind h
Go ahead. He holds the bicycle steady and trots alongside her while goes in circles around the edge of the roof.
Wajda sits on her bed tuning her radio. She stops, linger then idly turns to the Koran station.
You are listening to the one and only Koran station. Tune in to hear your favorite readers. Now, Al Hudafi will recite Surat al Baqara.

In the name of Allah, the Beneficent, the Merciful. Alif Lam Mim. This Book, there is no doubt in it, is a guide to those who guard against evil. She lies down in her bed listening. Her gaze falls on the video game she just bought. Her Mot comes in and closes the Koran.
Don't leave the Koran open! Satan will spit in it!  74 75 51. Wajda jumps up, takes the video game box and leaves.
Wajda sits on the floor trying to hook the game to the sm TV in the living room. She fiddles around with the cords.
This game doesn't work on our “state-of-the-art TV”. Her Mother looks perplexed, then realizes.
Don't even think of it. Your Father will go mad if you mess up his TV. Wajda sighs, staring at the locked Majlis door, where her Father's TV sits.
Wajda listens as the teacher finishes a lesson passionate
Wajda, what do you think? Wajda takes a moment and exchanges a glance with Noura, w elbows Yasmine and rolls her eyes.
I think this competition is very hard for me. Noura and the girls all giggle.

But I heard on the Koran channel yesterday that if it is easy for you, you get only one reward. But if it is hard for you to read and remember you get two rewards. One for reading the Koran and one for the trouble you go through!
Thank you, Wajda, for sharing this with us. Girls, I want you all to take Wajda as an example of a person who tries hard and is devoted to God.  76 52. Noura and her cronies look dumbfounded.
(surprised) Thank you! ANOTHER TEACHER passes by and motions for the Koran teach They talk for a moment. She looks over at Wajda.
Ms. Hussa said she needs to see you. Go to her room now. I told her how well you're doing.
Wajda stands nervously in front of Ms. Hussa's desk.
